p.s: In the pages 328-332 of the book The Hate U Give by Angie Thomas published in 2019 Starr finds herself in a situation where she stands up for herself and for Khalil.
The scene takes place at the intersection where Khalil was shot and at the moment of the scene a protest for Khalil takes place.
Seven, DeVante, Chris and Starr arrive at the intersection only to see ana school bus with Just US for Justice written on the side and protestors with black hair brushes.
During that Starr reminisces about Khalil lying on that street and looking at her.
She is startled back to reality through the chant A hairbrush is not a gun! and then recognizes her attorney who is leading the chant.
The others also recognize her and join in on the chant, while Starr gets lost in the memory of Khalil's death.
Suddenly Starr also chimes in with full emotion.
Ms. Ofrah then sees them and asks them about being there.
Starr tells her that she wants to use her voice and do something to help.
She gets put on the patrol car and gets the bullhorn.
First nervous but then confident Starr speaks in front of the crowd and tells her part of the story.
She also adressesaddresses the cops and declares that they are not going to stop protesting.
At the end she states that the thing about Khalil is not how he died, but that he lived.
Starr is very hard on herself through the scene.
She is scared because she is unsure of herself standing in front of the crowd and telling her opinion and experience.
Ms. Ofrah and the people protesting make her confident enough to stand in front of the crowd.
The reason she decides to speak in the end seems to be partially spite and the need to speak about what really happened.
